title: How to Make Vegan Crepes

methods.name:
Making Basic Vegan Crepes[2]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Mix the vegan milk, water, margarine, flour, sugar, syrup, and salt in a bowl using a whisk.
steps.description: The batter should be thin and pourable. Crepe batter should be thinner than regular pancake batter. For best results, add the dry ingredients first (flour, sugar, and salt), followed by the wet ingredients (water, melted margarine, and milk). You can add ½ tsp vanilla to the mixture for extra flavour. If you don't have vegan milk, you can substitute it with water, although it won't be as flavourful. You could even use juice, such as orange juice or apple juice. The melted margarine can be substituted with oil, but it may not taste as good.

steps.headline: Cover the bowl and let it chill for at least two hours.
steps.description: This will allow the mixture to cool down and thicken.

steps.headline: Grease a skillet lightly with margarine or spray-on oil.
steps.description: Heat the skillet for about five minutes on medium heat or at 180°C (350°F) on an electrical skillet. If it is hot enough, water should sizzle on it. It doesn't matter what oil you use. Coconut oil is a good choice for this recipe. Avoid using palm oil as it is usually unethically sourced. Also avoid using oil that tastes strong, such as peanut oil, unless, of course, that's what you want. If the skillet isn't hot enough, the crepes might end up with a gummy-like consistency.

steps.headline: Pour about three tablespoons of crepe batter onto the skillet.
steps.description: Make sure the batter fully covers the bottom of the skillet. Swirl the skillet around to help cover the base. Using a ladle makes the process easier.

steps.headline: Cook until one side is golden.
steps.description: When the first side has colour, flip the crepe over with a spatula (or without a spatula if you are experienced enough) making sure it is flat, and heat the other side until golden. It should take about two minutes per side. Wait for the top to bubble and the edges to brown.

steps.headline: Repeat the process to make about 16 crepes in total.
steps.description: You may need to add more oil or margarine while making the crepes so they don't stick to the skillet.

steps.headline: Serve the crepes with syrup, vegan chocolate spread, vegan cream, fruit, cinnamon or any other topping.

methods.name:
Making Gluten-Free Vegan Crepes[3]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Whisk together the flour, syrup, flaxseed, and vegan milk in a mixing bowl.
steps.description: The batter should be liquid. Leave for a few minutes to thicken, but be sure the mixture doesn't become too thick. If you don't have vegan milk, you can replace it with water, but the resulting crepes will not have as much flavour as they would with milk.

steps.headline: Grease the skillet with margarine or oil.
steps.description: Spray-on oil is recommended to decrease the amount of oil that is used. Try to avoid oil with a strong flavour. Coconut oil is a good option.

steps.headline: Pour enough batter into the heated skillet to cover the bottom.
steps.description: Swirl the batter around in the pan to make sure it fully covers the base. The skillet should be on medium heat or 180°C (350°F). You can test the heat by sprinkling a little water on it to see if it sizzles. To make pouring the batter easier, use a ladle. The crepes won't have the same texture if the skillet isn't hot enough. Give it about five minutes to heat up.

steps.headline: Heat one side of the crepe until it is golden brown.
steps.description: Each side should be heated for about 2-3 minutes, though the first one may need longer. Flip it over, flattening any creases, and heat the other side in the same way. Do this for all pancakes. This recipe makes around four crepes. Flip the pancakes when the edges brown and the center bubbles. Overcooking can cause the crepes to become rubbery.

steps.headline: Enjoy the crepes with sugar, jam (jelly), syrup, vegan chocolate spread, nut butter, fruit, or anything else you want.
steps.description: Serve the crepes hot, if possible.

methods.name:
Making Vegan Chocolate Crepes[4]
	X
		Research source

steps.headline: Mix the flour, egg replacer, vegan milk, sugar, and cocoa powder together in a bowl using a balloon whisk.
steps.description: Leave the mixture to set for a few minutes. The mixture should have a fluid consistency. If it does not, add more vegan milk or water. It's best to mix the dry ingredients first (flour, sugar, and cocoa powder), before adding the wet ingredients (milk and egg replacer). You could use water instead of vegan milk if you don't mind your pancakes having less flavour.

steps.headline: Grease the skillet with margarine or oil.
steps.description: If using oil, consider using spray-on oil to reduce the amount of oil used. Heat the skillet on medium heat until hot. This should take about five minutes. Coconut oil is a good option for greasing the skillet but other oils work too, as long as they don't have a strong flavour. An electrical skillet should be at about 180°C or 350°F.

steps.headline: Heat both sides of the crepes for a few minutes each.
steps.description: Add more oil or margarine to the skillet as necessary. Ensure that the batter covers the bottom of the pan fully, you may need to swirl it around a bit. When the top bubbles, it's time to flip them. Crepes cook fast, so avoid overcooking them or they will be chewy.

steps.headline: Serve the crepes with vegan chocolate spread (such as vegan Nutella), vegan chocolate sprinkles or shavings, vegan cream, fruit, or anything else you think would work.
steps.description: They are best served warm, but can be cooled.
